reviews.review_title: Congrats to everybody who made this happen
reviews.content:
I hope anybody has seen the original movie by the Coen brothers.
While the first season can be seen as a adaptation of their work, one can say that the density of its thrilling and funny moments was as good as in the movie.
I was totally hooked by the 1st season and even more by the 2nd.
The creators, showrunners, actors, the detailed work of the whole team...they have done a splendid job altogether and made a lot of series-fans happier.

"There are no saints in the animal kingdom. Only breakfast and dinner" -Lorne Malvo I'm going to be completely honest. I only turned on the TV to watch 1x01 "The Crocodile's dilemma" because of Martin Freeman. He is my favourite actor right now, I knew he was gonna rock whatever part he played, and I was so excited to hear his American (Minnesotan) accent. While I am proud to announce that he didn't disappoint, he is not the only great thing this show has to offer by a LOOOOOOONG shot. Spoiler-free, the only thing I can say is that whoever checks into this show, from the first episode to the last, you are in for one HECK of a ride. A solid and well-thought out script. Realistically scary performances, especially when it came to Billy Bob Thornton as Lorne Malvo, a malevolent intimidating man who is both the God and the Devil in the figurative sense. Freeman as Lester Nygaard is one of life's victims, but slowly and surely he soon starts to figure out that there's another way to live life that doesn't include following the rules. Allison Tolman as the determined and kind Molly Solverston, the true heart of the show, and our real hero. In a story with so many shades of grey, it's nice to have a character that you can actually pinpoint and say "Yup, Good Guy (girl)." The show is mature in every sense of the word, but isn't afraid to let loose and show off it's comedic, childish or inappropriate side at times. I found the two sex scenes in the entire show to be a little bit much, but that's just me. Symbolism and Metaphors are everywhere, some that I'm still scratching my head about. This isn't just a show that you watch and forget about the next day, I don't think I'm going to forget this show for the rest of my LIFE. All I wanna do is watch the whole thing all over again, and I know that I'll have just as much fun going on the roller coaster as I did the first time! "Because some roads you shouldn't go down. Because maps used to say "There be dragons here." Now they don't. But that don't mean the dragons aren't there" -Lorne Malvo.
Everything about this show is top notch quality! Highly recommended

Fargo, in its best moments is beating Pulp Fiction at its own game, and that's quite a feat, but these are few and far between. I especially liked the undertaker with his own costume and sidekicks like some american wrestler. There are some other references and homages, like the one to the "Big Lebowski" (in S3) which is rather weak and superficial. The character of Mike Milligan (in S2) is also a poor and exaggerated imitation. There is some clever writing and appealing stylization in parts, but it's spoiled by a rather heavy hand in others. The "true story" angle is overdrawn and simply annoying, especially when a flying saucer immediately follows. Another great annoyance are the Jewish gangsters and the whole Jewish undercurrent. I get it, this was made by Jews, enough of this mishegas already. Not everything has to revolve around some recently mythologized ethnic identity, just as not all world events of all time have to revolve around the USofA, though try telling that to the Mormons. On the flip side, there is the brilliant parody of Reagan which has been done and overdone in the past but never with this degree of accuracy of bite. Very promising but too much stylization and pretense and not enough of that bite, suspense and for gods's sake, subtlety. A lot of it is cartoonish and not in a good way. What a shame.
At beginning of each episode they claim "This is a true story etc." however it;s fiction why the misleading intro?

I loved season 4. Chris Rock was exceptional. In the beginning it was, of course, extremely different from the other seasons and from the brutal reviews I had my doubts. I can not understand why so many people didn't like it. Can't wait for season 5!
Great story telling. You will love this amazing show, don't miss it!!

reviews.review_title: Without a doubt, this show will be remembered
reviews.content: After the conclusion of the first season I'm am absolutely sure that this show will be remembered for it's amazing writing,perfect acting, dark and fascinating subject material, and comedic tie ins. If you enjoyed the film by the coen brothers then you will, without a doubt, love this show. In my opinion it far surpasses the movie in excellence. It tells the story of a loser who's wife doesn't love him and regrets marrying him. He accidentally tells a hit man (played expert by Billy Bob Thornton) to kill a bully of his. Things escalate from here in a comepletely amazing spectacle of coincidences and murder that will keep you in the need of another episode.If you like anti hero stories like breaking bad, dexter, and The Sopranos then I'm sure you will fall in love with this quirky and mysterious show. I can't wait to see what happens in season 2.

Just watched the final episode and I have to say this has been a fantastic series. Billy bob Thornton as a clever but psychopathic mob hit-man was brilliant throughout playing the character to the fullest. Then there was Lester played by Martin Freeman of The Office and more recently Bilbo in The Hobbit, it took a little while to get used to Freeman's accent in the series, but his acting won me over and he was great as the bumbling hen pecked husband, who slowly changed as the series goes along. The show ran at a great pace and I thoroughly enjoyed every episode. I was a huge fan of the original film back in the 90's and this series, which is a totally different story to the film, still has the same atmosphere and feel as the film and is all the better for it.

The opening statement is a lie. Most of the events in the show are fictional and have no factual basis whatsoever.It's a shame that a media production claiming everything "has been told exactly as it occurred" contains so few elements of truth.The 1996 movie with the same name started with the same lie and became a success. However in today's internet era it has been much easier for people to find the truth. The producer need to be reminded of that FACT. Overall this show is of quite good quality and more enjoyable than most other shows. I would have given it a 8 out of 10 had not been for the deceptive beginning message.

reviews.review_title: First 2 seasons amazing. Third season... Not so much
reviews.content: If only the first two seasons existed this may be the best show on television or second best. But season 3 was such a disappointment. Ewan McGregor was a good actor. Playing 2 characters was impressive. But anyways, the first 2 seasons were breaking bad level nearly. And ya.

Throughout the early episodes of Fargo this season, I was with the camp who felt that, although the season is good, it just didn't feel like Fargo. After watching the two most recent episodes, however, I feel they were saving the faithful Fargo tropes for later (while possibly establishing new ones early on).The latest two episodes have delivered the much anticipated violence viewers have come to expect from the series. Hard decisions have been made and key players have fallen. The series has finally started tying this to earlier seasons through the characters' actions and words (the whipping with the belt and the basically word-for-word "it's how you're unfriendly" speech are just a couple of examples).I never thought that this season was "bad," just a little too disconnected, however with what I've seen lately, I'm excited for what I hope will be a thrilling finish (will we meet a younger Floyd Gerhardt?).And if you still don't think this season is Fargoesque enough, you've come this far, you might as well finish it.

I absolutely adored Breaking Bad and was very sad after its finale. For months I searched and searched to find the "next" show. True Detective was solid but it's 8 episodes did little to satiate my appetite. Then I found Fargo. From the pilot I knew this show was going to be insane and incredible and it hasn't let up at ALL over the course of the season. The acting is superb and the plot intricate and compelling. The wait for Sherlock to return is NOT fun, but Martin Freeman's brilliant work as Lester is helping me get by. Billy Bob Thornton is also at his best in every episode. I'm already dreading the wait before next season, but I know I'll make it somehow. At this point it's not quite as good as Breaking Bad got to be at the end, but I say Fargo is already better than the first few years of BB and has no where to go but up. Everyone should get watching this show because in a few years, everyone will be watching it. I love it and can't wait for season 2! FX has really stepped their game up recently.
The second season is perfectly crafted and a real piece of cinematic artwork. Charakters are developed perfectly and the story has it all.

reviews.review_title: Season 3: A complete hotch-potch of garbage ..CONTAINS SPOILERS!
reviews.content:
I thoroughly enjoyed both seasons 1 and 2 but season 3 is a mess.
SPOILER ALERT *******
The whole idea of a series is that the parts eventually fit together to form a whole. This bit seems to have been omitted entirely in season 3.S3 Episode 3 was all about the sci-fi books, We had a flashback to how the young author was scammed, we had a cartoon representation of book, we had officer Burgle flying to LA to investigate/interview. And then, nothing because the books had zilch to do with the plot?
I mean, 1/10th of the series had nothing to do with the plot?? Yep!Then we had the Russian baddie Yuri Gurka, remember him?
After spending days relentlessly hunting down Nikki Swango, he goes into a bowling alley, is chatted to by a random guy (supposedly a homage to the cowboy in the Big Lebouski??) who tells him a story about 17th century Jews..and he disappears from the series, just like that???Or, how about the scene where Emmet Stussy's car breaks down, Swango arrives and confronts him, she's involved in a shoot out with police and Stussy makes his escape. Except..he makes his getaway in the very same car which had broken down two minutes earlier!!!Then there were the subliminal messages put there for no reason other than to demonise Russia notice them?
As in the story about Jews being killed by Russians in the 1700's.
Or the prominent picture of Lenin on display each time Varga was working on his computer (and why would a globalist, capitalist have a picture of a communist leader on his wall?)There were some good performances from the lead actors but otherwise the storyline was totally banal, and not in a good way.
I have no inclination to search out season 4, if it ever comes out.
An abject lesson in how to ruin a good series.

Funny when it had to be funny, violent when required, emotional when needed. This was perhaps the best series of 2014 alongside True Detective. There have always been doubts about a TV to Movie or movie to TV spin off but this one was genius. Not only the story was good, but the direction was quite amazing too. Plus a cast that everyone dreams of. If someone was missing Breaking Bad like crazy(just like me) I think this is the show that can fill that gap left by Breaking Bad. The connection showed to the movie was quite brilliantly presented too. You might not notice it, but it'll be there. The whole cast was brilliant but Martin Freeman stole the show for me. At one moment he'll be a dangerous and mean guy and at another he'll be a miserable timid middle aged man. His transformation was excellent. Summarizing it, there couldn't be any better dark humor show than this. it's a must watch.

reviews.review_title: Season 4 is off to a great start
reviews.content: The last 3 seasons were amazing, and Season 4 DOES NOT disappoint. An original spin on organized crime in America- this time in 1950s Kansas City- interesting character development and beautiful cinematography. Oh, and Jason Schwartzman & Chris Rock deliver solid performances, as does the supporting cast.
The Show was at The beginning Slow and i thougut Maybe it needs More Time to get into it but After Episode 5 I couldn't force Myself anymore to Watch this stupid Show! So overrated.

Well, To be Honest, after reading some of the reviews and ratings, I gave this series a try. Although at first I had a comparison of this show to "Breaking Bad" comparing as "Walter White's" Character is somewhat likewise to that of "Lester Nygard" but then after couple of episodes when it got intense, I was like NO WAY these two can be compared as they belonged to entirely different leagues. Now, What is amazing about this show is that all the movies like "Rush", "Captain Philips", "We are Marshall's" etc., have a TRUE STORY Inspiration which is moulded into excellent watch by some of the finest Talents in the movie industry. "FARGO" is the best of them in Television yet (True Stories Explained).Billy Bob Thornton is the best as Lorne Malvo. Excellent with his baleful influence with a cunning smile everywhere. And Martin Freeman is simply astonishing with the character of "Lester Nygaard" Oh he so lives up in the character that for a moment I had a doubt that 'is this the same fella as Dr. Watson from Sherlock ?' and to my amusement he is although he must have really worked hard to get that accent perfected.All the cast were put as they should have and the performance of each and everyone of them was astounding, even the 'Hess' Kids.The Story is so gripping that I watched it Non-Stop for Ten Straight Hours Jumping the Lunch as well on a Saturday morning. I Recommend it for all and I Hope it continues to Amaze me with another series (I Hope The Coen Brother can come up with something)

reviews.review_title: I rewatch each series over again, awesome story lines!!
reviews.content: This is a same somewhat different story of the Movie. Check it out you guarantee you do enjoys something from this series and the episodes

Your heart comes out when you read that "based on true events" tag at starting. After breaking bad & Chernobyl. This is the 3rd one in my list of best shows ever made. This is must watch show. Not many ppl you find talking about Fargo. Unlike GoT or BB. But this is not less in any way. Much recommended and must watch show!

reviews.review_title: Can't wait for the next episode.
reviews.content: As an lover of the original film, there is always skepticism with a show like this. After watching the pilot episode I must say that it was a very enjoyable watch. The dark and sometimes humor filled tone of the original in transported into the series through clever and quick dialogue. The characters are casted very well with Billy Bob Thornton brilliantly dark whilst Martin Freeman is great as Lester Nygaard. Fans of the 1994 original will enjoy the pilot immensely as it inter-twines the same feeling as the Coen Brothers movie. It's good that the Coen brothers have involvement with this project as I'm sure it will help the future episodes stay true to the source material.I can't wait for the next episode and I'm sure it will be a great first season. 10/10 (pilot)

Given the tough job of emulating the success of the movie by the Coen brothers, Noah Hawley has done what many thought was the unachievable and created something that is equal, if not better than the 1996 classic bearing the same name. The fantastic visuals and irresistible soundtrack is accompanied by fresh writing and brilliant acting. With each season being self contained as a miniseries, the writers are able to create a gripping storyline which encompasses you as a viewer. Season 1 follows the journey of Lester Nygaard from an emasculated male to becoming a cold hearted killer. With the same wit and dark humour that the movie possessed, Fargo creates the aura of reality and a certain terrifying and chilling aspect, initially provoked by the initial warning before every episode. Perhaps the greatest aspect of Fargo, for which it has become synonymous with is its unexpected bursts of violence. These horrific acts give the feeling that no one is safe and has you legitimately fearing for the characters life, exceptional edge of your seat viewing. The writers of the show deserve great applause for their ability to explore and flesh out the flaws of each character and have you confused for which character you want to live or die. Fargo represents what is truly great about the golden age of television. With its impeccable score and amazing visuals it delivers a final product which deserves to be ranked amongst one of the modern greats.

Considering that I think Fargo the movie is one of the best of all time, I wasn't sure if the TV show would measure up. But it did indeed! It feels very much like the movie, but still has its own completely different storyline. I'm amazed by the detail, the quirkiness, and the humor of the story. Great job! There's a great job done with casting. Billy Bob Thornton is just awesome as the evil Malvo. The characters are very well written and a delight to watch. Spoiler: Episode four pays homage to the movie linking the two story lines. See if you catch it. If you love quirky, funny, and dark mysteries, this one will blow you away. I can't wait to see the series finale coming up next week.
Seasons 1 and 2 were great. 3 and 4 not nearly as good but entertaining.

reviews.review_title: reflecting the ugliest side of mankind with a perfect balance of humor
reviews.content: I love the way Fargo is directed and written - with such smoothness in all its perfection. Because it is not an easy thing to take such severe and tragic incidents and tell them in a way where the humor doesn't get too degrading for any of the people involved in these events. I rate this show 10/10 based on the excellent use of the humorous element; the audience get their share amount of laughs but not on the expanse of the victims integrity. If you haven't seen Fargo yet you are in for a treat!

reviews.review_title: a story so out there, but told in a way it couldn't be made up. passive aggressive gangsters FTW.
reviews.content: just enough violence, just enough dialogue and a pace that never needed slowing down or speeding up. the series uniquely uses humor and passive aggressiveness to create a serious story and tone. the way events unfold and the story is told makes each episode original, intriguing, and intelligent, it didn't feel cheap or cheesy. each line, each scene had a purpose, there was nothing that needed to be trimmed or added and the acting was great, not one character seemed out of place or annoying. as it states, it was based on a true story and the story is so out there and told in such a way that there was no way it was made up. truly original gangsterness

reviews.review_title: The Greatest Television Show of All Time
reviews.content: Prior to Fargo there had never been a television show capable of crafting such a unique and brilliant story. Fargo has since done it four times. The interweaving of stories made it possible for millions of people to feel like they have inhabited this twisted version of Fargo, North Dakota for all their lives. A truly remarkable achievement.
Each season has more and more twisted turns and surprises.

Actually i didn't enjoy a single episode , my friends told me season 2 is better than s1 which is not the case . The problem with Fargo is the Pulb Fiction of it all . Like there is nothing that make sense in it but in the worst way . Season 1 was all about the connections about the original movie :
some shots , character names and whatnot ,However the series didn't take the effort to make it logical instead of creating nonsensical plot twists in every episode . For example :
S1. The character Lester decides to kill his wife after having a talk with Lorne Malvo , well for someone who is a coward most of his life i find it very odd that he is capable of doing that . But this is not the messed up part , the fact that Lorne Malvo trusted Lester and made friends with him almost immediately without anything to get back is . Like why would someone like Malvo ever cares about Lester that he goes to kill Sam Hess for free and gives his contact number to Lester killing an officer again for him without getting anything back from him ? The movie does do this , the salesman does hire kidnappers to his wife .Second of all , why malvo is killing all of these people ? Because he is just a philosopher believing that men must turn into wolves ? Well , is not because he works people up to scam them ?? You can't find a single motive for his character he is just there to create tension . He is poor resemblance of the mute character in the movie where he eventually got arrested but here Malvo was willing to lose his money just because Lester said yes to kill these people in the elevator .S2. Is way worse cause we see a stupid couple with UFO's to show up every now and then ,there is no genius to it at all . Ed and Piggy all of the sudden decided to be killers , lying to the cops and hiding a body. To realize at the end. That the couple don't really belong to each other after all , like seriously. How many dead bodies there need to be to have them realized that yeah is true that they both are idiots ? Its another cheap copy from Bonnie and Clyde but at Fargo as always change characters' faith so its poor adaptation .The cop always let people go if you noticed , he let the black guy and the two who pulled a gun at him go , he let hanze get away and he was so poor at doing his job because he couldn't catch lead or solve anything it was all just coincidence which makes his character unlike any crime drama a boring one . He didn't do any arrest to anybody even though people always pull a gun at him .and he didn't even get Ed and Piggy get arrested when he had the chance .Why Hanzee did what he did ? Because he wanted to build a gang himself or an empire . Well he needed his identity changed and of course alot of money so what is the best way to do that ? Is to kill everyone . He shot people in the street and a restaurant owner and who were the people behind them.it wasn't clear at the end .This show tries so hard to be smart and entertaining but fails pathetically to introduce a decent tv show . Overrated and cheap .

The first three seasons are all very similar in their concepts and deliver wonderfully in what they are intending to accomplish. The fourth season has received heavy criticism with it veering from the traditional Fargo plot and is a much different show than the previous three seasons, however it is in my opinion still very good. I think that the change of direction that the producers took with season 4 was refreshing while still maintaining classic elements of the nostalgic film style.

reviews.review_title: Remember Leo Tolstoy's tales of the devil and the man ?
reviews.content: Open your heart to evil and Fargo follows. Fargo is a dark and haunting story, beautifully told with brutal honesty. It will sadden your very soul. Still watch it, and you'll appreciate life, truth and goodness with a new perspective.I could write pages with adjectives for Fargo, but suffice to say that It will stir something deep inside you. Isn't that what all great works of art do ? PS - Fargo does full justice to the movie. When the first season ended I could almost hear Marge saying, "...And here ya are, and it's a beautiful day. Well. I just don't understand it. "

Season 1 was brilliant. As to season 2, it was mediocre, I tried to watch it two times, but couldn't keep watching past episode 3 because it was unimpressive and dull. But season 3 blew my mind. Season 3 follows the best traditions of the first season: colorful characters, funny subliminal details and things like that.

From the very first episode, the show keeps you glued to your television sets. The transformation of Lester Nygaard (Martin Freeman) from being an innocent loser to a coldblooded criminal has been portrayed exceptionally. Billy Bob Thornton plays a dark, merciless hit-man, Lorne Malvo. The series brilliantly describes the train of events which follow their first meeting at a hospital.Not having seen the "Fargo", the 1996 movie , I didn't face any difficulty understanding the characters, their past, or the storyline in general. It is a standalone series and watching the movie is NOT a prerequisite. With the correct amount of humour, great characterisation, and outstanding performances by all the leads, the series can be counted amongst the best in its genre. However, this series would not be appreciated by all. With a tremendous amount of blood and violence, the series is ideal for dark comedy lovers, or lovers of the crime genre in general. It would be unfair to judge the show entirely on the basis of its first season, as the coming season appears to be narrating a different incident altogether.

reviews.review_title: Ignore the other reviews for season 4
reviews.content: Season 4 is great. Season 1 was amazing but season 2 and 3 fizzled out just a bit. Still amazing TV. Those complaining about season 4 not being Fargo have other complaints not related to the show due to our current societal situations. Season 4 has quirky characters and untimely deaths. I have seen many complaints that season for is "political." That's your prerogative if you want to apply it to the Black vs white narrative that you see in the news. My opinion is it's an engaging story with the Cohen brothers touch. I found it to be as enjoyable as the other seasons.

reviews.review_title: Might become one of the most important shows of this decade.
reviews.content: I must start by commending the great piece of writing in this show. Mysterious, unpredictable, unfathomable characters and sudden plot changes keep you glued to your seat and your eyes on screen. The cast is vast and I like how they intertwine with each other and cross each other's paths in several ways. Characters share a common history in many ways. Superb dialogues, great cinematography, locations, clothing, all of which contributes to the overall image of the show. I have not seen anything like this before, the closest it matches to is True Detective but True Detective is rather more dark, grotesque and serious. I think it might become one of the important shows of this decade. And I think that the quality of television shows is increasing tremendously in general after shows like Breaking Bad and the quality in movies is sort of deteriorating and I say this because of this show.10/10 from me.

reviews.review_title: Would've given a higher rating if not for the blatant lie
reviews.content: Overall it's an enjoyable series but why would you put the "This is a true story.." BS when it's in fact a fiction (only little part of it is based on real events)
Started watching this last night on Netflix and so far enjoying it.

reviews.review_title: The Number one TV show ever made!
reviews.content: I love this tv series! Season one was outstanding! Season 2 and 3 weren't bad either. The story and the direction is exemplary and the acting by Billy Bob and Bilbo Baggins is amazing! I don't even know how to describe the emotions I get when I watch this show.The jaberwock scene was unreal!

I watched only the 1st season.
Such a boring story..not even a true one! The only good thing was the snowy place!

I love this. New and old, great on so manny leves.
But you can not start with the episodes with, the text that this is true. It is not, it cant be. I dont care if you lie to the police or your mom. But a network like HBO can not do this. What is next. That HBO supports trump and becomes the Fox News of serries. I hate that they lie like that. STOP IT.

Fargo is one of my favorite television shows of all time. Being of a younger generation, my parents would occasionally quote the original movie FARGO when talking about their favorite movies. The only thing I knew about the movie was that poster of the murdered cop lying in the snow. So when I heard it was being turned into a show, I took the opportunity to watch the season premier. I was instantly hooked. I was intrigued. I was horrified. I knew I was going to be in for an emotional, crazy ride.I don't like to write reviews that are all positive, but I really don't have anything bad to say about this show. Each episode is a 50 minute movie the progresses the plot. Even with 1 or 2 slower episodes, every episode is crucial for the finale. The character development is amazing. The acting and writing is spot on. The music works perfectly to keep you on your seat. Billy Bob Thornton just became one of my new favorite actors. FARGO keeps the drama and thrills to the very end. You don't watch FARGO, you are apart of it.If you are looking for a show that is deep, thought provoking, and thrilling, FARGO is the show. It will make you think about society and crime. It does not spoon feed you. You have to make the decision. What if they are wrong, and you are right?
The first three seasons are great. Season 4 saw a huge drop in quality and I couldn't even finish the season. Hoping Season 5 is good again. Season 1 and 2 are still my favorite.

reviews.review_title: One of the best I seen
reviews.content: After braking bad this show is impress me. Every season is defrant but so same. Which is one of the point I like.

There aren't many TV series that I can become fixated too. Fargo is my only exception. I cant honestly say that I have ever watched anything more intriguing, exciting and enjoyable. With countless plot twists, superb acting and scenes that stir with your emotions Fargo certainly can't go without a miss. Staring Martin Freeman, Billy Bob Thornton and Colin Hanks (Tom Hank's son) it doesn't boast an A-list of star celebrities but I must say their acting in extremely complex roles was superbly executed. If your bored of the typical and slightly predictable shows like Walking Dead and House of Cards then take some time out to watch this. I promise you won't regret it.

reviews.review_title: 2nd series even better than the first
reviews.content: Second series of Fargo is one of the best TV shows I have ever seen. For me the first episode was a bit hard to swallow with all the visual story telling retro-avant garde. However, once you get used to it, the story and the cast is breathtaking right from the start.The parallels of the touching family story, the story of the criminals by accident and the war of the gangs all framed by a series of deus-ex-machina UFO apparitions is just amazing!The contrasts between the Kansas City Gang, Solverson, Gerhard and the Blumquist family characters are crowned by the incredible performance of Kirsten Dunst as Peggy Blumquist and her male counterpart Jesse Plemons as Ed the butcher whose absurd love story just blew my mind from the beginning till the end. The 2nd series is thrilling, dark and incredibly funny at the same time. It pulls you into the depicted era and the almost biblical/magical realism/mini-saga, which tackles deep subjects like values in life, the nature of good&evil, bravery&cowardice and the sources of conflicts between people on so many levels.

reviews.review_title: A bit strange for a true story
reviews.content: I do agree with most reviewers who commented after watching the pilot.Undoubtedly it starts of pretty well.However,as one moves forward to episode 02 and 03 the ineptitude of the police departments involved in solving the crime becomes appalling.If this indeed is a factual account of events as they transpired (supposedly a few years ago)then the foremost question that needs an answer is:Being a moron is a mandatory qualification to join the Minnesota police force?How can a community rely on this kind of law enforcement and its not a single stray officer but a pack of idiots. Anyway this so called true account of events shames the wildest of fables.UPDATE:Even Coen brothers "Fargo" was a fictitious saga and consisted of various cases knitted together from different states.Ergo that explains the far fetched story line and ridiculous coincidences.

I could have easily given a 10. When I first heard of this, I thought they were going to ruin one of my favorite movies. When I watched the first few minutes of the first episode I thought "oh no, they're ripping off the movie". By the 10 minute mark, I was fully engrossed and knew this is brilliant. I've never thought much of people in my office who rave about a television series. Now, I'm one of them. FX has it's biggest winner, in my opinion. What fascinates me even more is that it's based on a true story from 2006(?). Billy Bob Thornton reveals insight to everyday murder with some hard to deny reasoning and a wicked sense of humor. Martin Freeman's role reminds me the most of the original. He does a fine job. Allison Tollman didn't quite replicate the movie character, and that's OK. She didn't need to. She made it her own. I have never been captivated by a television series, until now. I'll change it to a 10.

This show may not be for everyone, but for the people it was made for, dam is it good. Season 1 and 2 are perfect, season 3 is close to perfect and season 4 misses the mark a bit but is still better than most TV these days in my opinion. I would recommend this series to anyone and everyone.

reviews.review_title: The show which you're gonna love 2nd time
reviews.content:
The drama the moment which you keeps on the edge on the seat,the conspiracy the mind
The courage
Youre gonna love it

reviews.review_title: Season 2 will go down in history as possibly the greatest art distributed via TV
reviews.content: The best way to summarize the greatness of Fargo season 2 is try and imagine a sequel to PULP FICTION coming out within a year of the release of the first one. Yes, every single episode from season 2 has a perfect 100% on RT. Yes, the soundtrack is one of the greatest in the history of media. Yes, the acting, yes, the writing....the sets. On and on and on. Pretend it's an Avengers film and begin with the cop as Captain America.

reviews.review_title: Okay. It's A Good Show. But Is Nothing Sacred?
reviews.content: Look, this is a fine TV series. But it's not Fargo. Fargo (the movie) is legendary because two talented guys, who had just bombed with a PG flick, took something like $8 million and some strong writing and made movie history. With Fargo (the TV series), $8 million probably doesn't even cover BBT's salary. Frankly, the show is high quality. It looks like a 2014 big-budget series on cable. But other than the character's accents --which have been beaten to a bloody pulp-- and a few rip-off situations, this show has no connection to the legendary film. Call it: Dakota. Call it: Blood Simple (no wait, don't). Call it anything else. But don't call it Fargo. Innovation at 90% is admirable, but it leaves one to wonder: what is the agenda of that other 10%?
That's it. Nothing more to say. Series 4 is the best.

Yes, you should watch this show, all seasons, will episodes, and multiple times. This show is amazing with superb writing, acting, cinematography, narrative and character development, mise en scene, and diegetic and non diegetic elements. Each season acts as it's own independent narrative with some what of a interlocking story based around the mid west city of Fargo and the state of Minnesota. This show is technically amazing, story is unreal yet based on actually events with an unpredictable yet realistic characters.So why is this not a perfect 10? The reason is the following seasons. The first season is an 11 if possible. The characters are meaningful, interesting, and despite their choices the audience can't help but sympathise with them. However, in the 2nd and 3rd season, the characters fall some what flat as the audience does not have as much of an attachment to them. What causes this lack of attachment could be caused by a number of things, from total character development to simple editing timeline. If the seasons are to improve as the show continues, without any second thoughts this review will be updated to an instant 9 or 10. I am in love with this show and vibes and the entirely of how amazing this show is. Despite what I have said about the other seasons, you should definitely watch them as they are way better then any current thriller mystery crime show that is on air at the moment.

reviews.review_title: A little slow, but worth watching.
reviews.content: Good cast. Billy Bob kind of makes the show. There is a sense of awkwardness throughout the show that makes you want to continue watching and see where the characters will take things. You start to develop mixed feelings towards certain main characters. The show does a good job at being unpredictable. Lots of unexpected turns. Its not a very straight forward plot. Worth the watch if you are into slow building stories.

reviews.review_title: My Favorite Movie and Favorite TV Shows are mirror images of each other.
reviews.content: In the next few minutes I will make a play on telling how my favorite TV show and favorite movie align themselves as mirror images of one another. More succinctly I find great similarities between Fargo Season 2 and Quentin Tarantino's Hateful 8. I would point to plagiarism on someone's part however the close proximity to which both were released make it more like a wild coincidence. Then again Partridge Brady. Munsters Adams. These things do happen fast. Rather than put you through the drudgery of reading my lengthy treatise, I will put down my thoughts in note form. Bokeem Woodbine's character is very much like Samuel L. Jackson's character in his preference for the full hairdo and the quoting of brainy ideas..usually right before an execution. I know Hateful 8 and Fargo season 2, so allow me to get back on track. Both Fargo Season 2 and Hateful 8 have colorful villains who are both comic strip like and terrifying. Both shows culminate in a bloodbath. Both have murders that take place, but then the scene cuts to the beginning where an unassuming, non-threatening voiced narrator attempts to give clarity or the mystery. The colored, ur... ah, African American gentleman in both features is an anti-hero who has definitive quirks that have allowed him to succeed despite being outnumbered and trifled with at every other turn for being a Colored, Ur..a... I mean... African American gentleman. Both feature a Sheriff who is an old school throw back to by the book law enforcement and modeling of proper behavior which makes their character beyond reproach. Lest not forget, the haunting yet mischievous sneakily running forward beat Soundtrack that netted Hateful an Oscar is heard in short order variation throughout the most pivotal scenes of Fargo Season 2.

I quit watching half an hour into this sexist, insulting piece of garbage. The movie is one of my favorites of all time. Yet I soon discovered that the best character in it--and the only female not a stripper or a hooker, or a housewife with no lines beyond nods or screeches--had been changed into a man. A perfect flawless man with a none-too-bright pregnant wife at home and a dingbat moron employee sidekick. Take out a brilliant woman and add 2 more stereotypes...did the Coen brother married to the star of the movie version get divorced and try to divorce the movie character as well? That was the inescapable feeling I got, and enough to make me shut off after the 2d moronic group of comments by the now-demoted female cop and the corrections to her flawed reasoning by her new boss, the now-male police chief. I wish the Coen Brothers were sentenced to read the book Backlash cover to cover for ruining a great movie's memory. I still have the DVD if I ever forgive them tho I'll never watch this tripe of a TV show. It's a shame people are still so unenlightened they buy into such stereotypes, judging by all the good reviews.

reviews.review_title: Season 1 & 2 were phenomenal, Season 3 casting is a bit cringe
reviews.content: Season 1 & 2 were absolutely astounding! 10/10. Cinematography was top notch, for all seasons, screenplay and dialogue, character development were really setting the bar for the crime genre.The problem with making such a great season of a television series is being able to top that quality of execution the very next season. Season 1 set the bar, and Season 2 definitely met it. But Season 3... Hmm..I'm watching Season 3 now, and I cannot help but cringe at the casting. Specifically the fact that they cast David Thewlis as VM Varga. Thewlis is great when he's typecast in gritty roles like in Harry Potter. But Thewlis definitely SHOULD NOT have been cast for this role. V.M Varga is suppose to be intimidating, but Thewlis's portrayal is just so cringe. Every time he delivered a line of dialogue it just made me want to look away from the screen. It may be the fact that he had taken a 2 year break from acting before taking this role, but honestly I just believe he's just not suited. V.M Varga is suppose to come off as a smart, articulate and well spoken intimidating criminal in lower class clothing. But Thewlis's portrayal just come off as tacky and cringe. When his character first appeared on screen and delivered lines of dialogue I actually thought the entire time that he was playing a down syndrome character or something. Just wanted to punch his character in the fact every time I saw him.I know Jake Gyllenhaal isn't a television actor, but you guys should've cast someone like him instead. Jesus, I could do the casting way better than the season 3 casting director. Give me the job!

With season 4 coming out in a month and the pandemic I finally got around to watching this. I've been a really big Coen brothers fan for a while which I think caused a few problems for me in this show especially in season 1. I'm going to write short reviews for each season due to how different each one is.Season 1 was great but was definitely my least favorite season without much competition. It makes the most sense when you hear about a show based on the movie Fargo because it tries very hard to be as much like the movie as possible which caused it to come off less original and it didn't have much of it's own personality to me. Billy Bob Thornton was an incredible villain, Martin Freeman gave one of his best performances and the first episode is one of my favorites.Season 2 was a step up for me and improved on almost every issue I had with the first season. The season being set in 1979 gave the settings and technology a lot of personality which is also why I'm excited for season 4 being in the 50's. The editing and directing was way more stylized than season one and gave it a unique feeling. A big reason I loved the season so much was every character and storyline was captivating and I was always deep into what was happening. There were choices made that felt like a Coen brothers idea but the Coen brothers never did it.Season 3 seems to be divisive among fans with most seeing it as the worst but for me it was tied with season 2 as my favorite. The reason I can't choose between the two seasons is they're so different. Season 2 is fun, has a lot of action, and has a lot of different characters and plots. Season 3 is very strange comparatively it's a lot more dismal, has a lot more scenes of just dialogue, and has fewer characters. This season left a bigger impression on me in the way that it was more psychological and had more meaning to it. This season probably has my favorite final episode in the show too. David Thewlis as V.M. Varga was probably my favorite performance from him and my favorite character in all of the series.This show started the same year as True Detective another crime anthology show which started off to bigger critical acclaim with an incredible first season but due to a disappointing second season it caused a drop in viewership with the third and people not being able to call the show itself great but just the first season. This is where Fargo prevails as it is an anthology show that improves each season or at least in my opinion is consistently great. This to me is the perfect example of how good anthology tv can be. This is definitely one of the best tv shows currently running and I have very good faith that season 4 will be incredible too.

From the first episode, the show explores the characters of Lester and Lorne Malvo. Lester being the submissive salesman, and Lorne Malvo, the dominating drifter who likes to mess with people, sometimes for his own amusement. The show is witty, with many thoughtful anecdotes and not moody and has all of the subtle dark comedy that the Coen Brothers are known for. The pilot was in my opinion the best pilot to have aired since Lost. The deaths were unpredictable, and the show never felt that it was dragging itself over. I felt the ending provided a good closure for the show, and despite having many connections managed to weave them together by the finale. Overall, the show was brilliant, and one of the best shows of last year.

SPOILER ALERT* Just a little. Why DOA you ask? A show about murder (or any television show for that matter) has to start off with a bang. Either literally or figuratively. S2:E1 of Fargo starts off with a barrage of information- of which only a few facts can be gleaned (sorry I don't speak Minnesotan)- family business, deals being made, brothers in hierarchy (natural tension) and finally, the patriarch dying. (All in two minutes) While this does set the scene for the rest of the season, do I care? No. The action happened so fast, it was comedic (and not in a good, dark Coen bros way.) Cold murder in otherwise unsuspecting places? Classic "Fargo." Dark humor? Classic Coen Brothers. While the first ep tries to stay true to that vein, the believability falls flat. Specifically, in the scene where a cherub Kristen Dunst (playing Peggy Blomquist- great name, invoking mundaneness) hides a man she hit by her car, and then pleads with her husband not to investigate, one wonders, wouldn't she be scared of a man bumping around her garage? When he does investigate and ends up killing the man, he goes for the man's gut and stabs him with a garden tool. Why wouldn't he just knock him out? And if you're thinking, "shit happens," then why wouldn't he be in shock? While I am a Jesse Plemons fan (Breaking Bad), he was just delivering his lines. His character, Ed Blomquist, merely concerns himself with his wife, Peggy. Not believable. Writing: Let's look at the writer to get to the bottom of this. Noah Hawley: Wrote all ten episode of Season 1. So what's the problem, then? (Can you tell I enjoyed Season 1?) Is there a room full of ghost writers? If so I suggest Hawley comes back to work. Directing: While I hate to attack the director, (I am one) I can see no other source of why it's bad. Michael Uppendahl and Randall Einhorn co-directed. Makes sense for Uppendahl- he directed American Horror Story (very campy) and Glee (definition of Camp). He did direct Mad Men though, and will I have heard good things, I haven't seen it. Einhorn on the other hand, has directed primarily comedies (Nurse Jackie, The Office, Wilfred, It's Always Sunny). Cinematography: Good. Visually beautiful, compositionally and in color and light. Yet, if the story is lacking, what is cinematography going to do? Sure, I can have this on mute and have it running for a dinner party for conversation starter, the equivalent of a coffee table book. Shots that pose problems: The split screen- technically used to show the viewer two pieces of information at once, it can be utilized to do amazing things for story and perception, considering this technique interrupts the eye's natural "stream of reality" with one screen. (Read a great list of top ten uses of split-screen in films.) Instead this episode shows Peggy Blomquist doing her makeup nervously, as a flashback, in contemplation for what she has done. The problem? It's boring. The shot where we see Kieran Culkin (Yes, his brother) playing Rye Gerhardt from a window outside the diner, nice, compositionally. Does it further the story? Does the fact that he appears in the last window, suggest he is a tad askew in personality, suggesting that it makes sense he just shot three people when he didn't need to? Could be. Shot to watch for in ep1: The slow motion sequence of the kitchen diner door swinging, while Gerhardt kills two people in seemingly one second, is beautiful. It exemplifies violence and how quick a situation can turn sour. Final Verdict: If you came for the stars, stay. (I might stay for Jean Smart- she barely got any lines this ep, and was hilarious in Designing Women) If you came for the story, hope that it well get better. If you value your time, leave, at least until someone else blogs that it did get better.

reviews.review_title: Fx Delivers An Amazing Show, Fargo Is The Next Breaking Bad.
reviews.content: Let me first start out by saying that Fargo has some of the best acting i have seen in a TV show yet. All the cast from Martin Freeman to Patrick Wilson knocks it out of the park. For those who don't know Fargo is an American Black Comedy Drama Series on the Network Series Fx. Let me get right to it and say that. The writing is so funny and quirky, its a very dark comedy drama that just doesn't let you off the edge of your seat. This is my first review for a TV show or movie ever and i feel that Fargo really deserves a 10/10, if you've never seen this show i would highly recommend it. The Directing is very coen brothers style, it really gives you that western type feel. Nothing that i have seen throughout my days of binge watching has kept me engaged in the story and the characters as much as Fargo has.While Shows like Breaking Bad and Lost have those amazing characters and story, it doesn't feel like its setting itself is a character like Fargo, you feel that everything is connected and theirs a bigger message its showing you. Overall Fargo is a must have TV experience for any TV show lovers out their.

I was Skceptical about the show when i started watching it as i had found Fargo the movie rather overrated and i knew the show would take some references from it;but boy oh boy,the pilot simply blew me away.This being the golden era in U.S. television,you involuntarily expect something special from almost every show that has a stellar cast like Fargo.And this was quite special. The writing was worthy of something like a Pulitzer. Episode after episode they had something brilliant to show. the acting was superb with no exceptions. Martin freeman did the accent quite well. Billy Bob Thornton exceeded all expectations and delivered a performance to behold.In a sea of TV shows all claiming to be the next big thing,Fargo is a quiet,beautiful mermaid waiting and deserving to be appreciated.

Crime thrillers don't get any better than this. Martin Freeman plays (with flawless American accent) a henpecked salesman who snaps. Billy Bob Thornton made my skin crawl as a sociopathic hit man. The filming and storytelling techniques are arty and fresh, but the theme is timeless: good vs evil. I liked this series even better than the film (with France McDormand) that told the same story a few years back. The season-long format allowed deeper character development and more room for pure style.Each episode of Fargo begins with a message on the screen, saying the story is true and that actual events unfolded just as they are shown. This is incorrect. The crime happened, but the TV series actually takes liberties with the facts for storytelling purposes. Not a deal breaker for me, but a manipulative thing for the show's creators to say.

But the real stand-out acting performances are form Billy Bob Thorton and Alison Tholman. Thorton's character makes the show. His violent, psychopathic character causes trouble wherever he goes, and he finds a great target in Lester Nygaard whose life is utterly destroyed by one sentence. Yes Or No?

Fargo contains some of the best storytelling and characters on TV. The Coen brothers influence can be felt throughout the series. It's violent, funny and sometimes absurd(especially in season 2).Noah Hawley and his crew are in the realm of genius that was found in Vince Gilligan and his crew. The writing is superb with slow- building tension in the second season. Fargo surpasses expectations in its technical prowess. Everything from set design, cinematography, costumes and dialogue is meticulously arranged in great periodic detail. The cast is perfectly chosen with Patrick Wilson, Kirsten Dunst, Ted Danson and Nick Offerman being the standouts. The villainous roles are perfectly executed with wit, humor and outright strangeness. The interesting Minnesota characters are masters of passive aggression. Polite exteriors cover a very violent displacement which makes for great characters and televisionFargo has the production values of film but it still remains grounded. The film was great but the series is excellent. Fargo deserves all the acclaim and awards it's getting. It is one of the shows that make the phrase "Golden Era of Television" plausible.

reviews.review_title: Most interesting show I have watched in a very long time.
reviews.content: Billy Bob Thornton was exactly what this show needed. I saw the movie but it didn't captivate me like this mini-series did. The writer combined with the actors/actresses were perfectly matched. There is no way I could miss a single week. I didn't want to miss an episode because every single one was intriguing. What was going to happen next? Who was Malvo going to get rid of next? He seemed to elude authorities constantly and it seemed impossible for them to locate him although he was in plain sight. The character of Lester was hilarious yet sneaky. How could there be very little suspicion cast upon him especially when his 2nd wife was murdered! I can't imagine what other true thrilling stories this writer can come up with to share with the world, but I hope the powers that be will allow it. I never viewed the movie with as much enthusiasm as I did this TV series. Please give us a 2nd season!!
